direction.raw_text: (offhand) Very impressive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (leafing through the magazine) Would you like to see how I treated it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can hardly wait. I'm sure I'll find out all sorts of fascinating things about the case that I never knew before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just what do you mean by that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, come now, Watson, you must admit that you have a tendency to over-romanticize. You have taken my simple exercises in logic and embellished them, exaggerated them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I deny the accusation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have described me as six-foot-four, whereas I am barely six-foot-one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bit of poetic license.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (removing Inverness and deerstalker) You have saddled me with this improbable costume, which the public now expects me to wear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not my doing. (indicating cover of Strand) Blame it on the illustrator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've made me out to be a violin virtuoso. Here -- 6. (holds out a letter he's been reading) -- a request from the Liverpool Symphony to appear as soloist in the Mendelssohn Concerto.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (excited) Oh, really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fact is that I could barely hold my own in the pit orchestra of a second-rate music hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're much too modest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (busy with the mail) You have given the reader the distinct impression that I am a misogynist. Actually, I don't dislike women -- I merely distrust them. The twinkle in the eye and the arsenic in the soup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's those little touches that make you colorful -- HOLMES Lurid is more like it. You have painted me as a hopeless dope addict -- just because I occasionally take a five per cent solution of cocaine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A seven per cent solution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five per cent. Don't you think I'm aware you've been diluting it behind my back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a doctor -- and as your friend -- I strongly disapprove of this insidious habit of yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear friend -- as well as my dear doctor -- I only resort to narcotics when I am suffering from acute boredom -- when there are no interesting cases to engage my mind. (holding out one of the open letters) Look at this -- an urgent appeal to find six missing midgets. He tosses the letter down is disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you say midgets? He picks up the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six of them -- the Tumbling Piccolos -- an acrobatic act with some circus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disappeared between London and Bristol ... Don't you find that intriguing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extremely so. You see, they are not only midgets -- but also anarchists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anarchists?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding) By now they have been smuggled to Vienna, dressed as little girls in burgundy pinafores. They are to greet the Czar of all the Russias when he arrives at the railway station. They will be carrying bouquets of flowers, concealed in each bouquet will be a bomb with a lit fuse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really think so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. The circus owner offers me five pounds for my services -- that's not even a pound a midget.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . So obviously he is a stingy blighter, and the little chaps simply ran off to join another circus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crestfallen) Oh.    And it sounded so promising -- HOLMES There are no great crimes anymore, Watson. The criminal class has lost all enterprise and originality. At best they commit some bungling villainy, with a motive so transparent that even a Scotland Yard official can see through it. He has crossed to the desk, suddenly notices something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angrily) Mrs. Hudson! (even angrier)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HUDSON! Mrs. Hudson comes hurrying out of the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?    What is it? What have I done now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sternly) There is something missing from my desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Missing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something very crucial. (picks up a small feather) You have been tidying up against my explicit orders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I made sure not to disturb anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dust, Mrs. Hudson, is an essential part of my filing system. By the thickness of it, I can date any document immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the dust was this thick. She demonstrates with her thumb and forefinger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (promptly) That would be March, 1883. He blows the feather away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you stand this? Why don't you let me air the room out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Mrs. Hudson -- he's working on a definitive study of tobacco ash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (drily) I'm sure there's a crying need for that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In our endeavors, it is sometimes vital to distinguish between, say, the ashes of a Macedonian cigarette and a Jamaican cigar. Sor far he has classified 140 different kinds of ashes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of which will end up on my rug. She is now pulling on the rope which lowers the dumbwaiter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That'll be enough, Mrs. Hudson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (heading for door) All right. If you gentlemen want to stay here and suffocate... She exits, shutting the door. For a while, the two go on working. Then Holmes rises abruptly from the chemistry table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's right.    I am suffocating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me open a window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not from lack of air -- from lack of activity. Sitting here week after week -- blowing smoke rings -- staring through a microscope -- there's no challenge in that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Personally, I consider it a major contribution to scientific criminology... Holmes has opened his violin case and taken out his fiddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How I envy you your mind, Watson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's placid, imperturbable, prosaic. But my mind rebels against stagnation. It's like a racing engine, tearing itself to pieces because it's not connected up with the work for which it was built. He has tucked the violin under his chin, starts to improvise a nervous pent-up melody. There is nothing amateurish about it -- he plays quite well. Watson resumes working on his manuscript. Suddenly the music stops. Watson looks up apprehensively. Holmes has put down the violin, and is crossing to the sideboard. He opens Watson's medical bag, takes out a bottle of cocaine, starts toward his bedroom. Watson pushes the writing arm to the side, rises from his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes -- Holmes   pays no   attention, continues into the bedroom. Watson   crosses   to the open door. Inside the bedroom, Holmes   has put   down the cocaine bottle on the washstand, and is   rolling   up his left sleeve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes, where is your self-control?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fair question. From a drawer he takes a morocco case, opens it, removes a hypodermic syringe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't you ashamed of yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thoroughly.    But this will take care of it. He has removed the stopper from the cocaine bottle, and inserting the hypodermic needle into it, starts to draw up the liquid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. BAKER STREET - DAY It is raining. A bus comes down the street, the open top deck sprouting umbrellas like black mushrooms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naturally, I don't mean to imply that my friend was always on cocaine -- sometimes it was opium, sometimes it was hashish. And once he went one of these dreadful binges, there was no telling how long it would last. INT. LIVING ROOM - 221B BAKER STREET - DAY Rain beats on the windows.    Holmes and Watson are in the middle of an argument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only reason you moved in with me is to have a steady supply of stimulants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, now, Watson -- you mustn't underestimate your other charms. He starts into the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes, I warn you. If you lock yourself in there once more -- HOLMES I intend to do nothing of the sort. He takes the hypodermic out of the drawer in the washstand, starts back into the living room with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not until you replace this needle.    It is getting rather blunt. As Watson glares at him, the door opens and Mrs. Hudson comes bustling in. Holmes hides the hypodermic behind his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I made you some tea and cress sandwiches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She opens the door of the dumbwaiter, starts to pull it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Hudson, I want you to pack my bags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going away for the weekend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And beyond.   I'm moving out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moving out? (she looks at Holmes)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just as surprised as you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard me, Mrs. Hudson.     And let's not waste any time. Mrs. Hudson sighs, exits into Watson's bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I be so bold as to ask where you'er going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know yet. But I intend to resume my practice. I am, after all, a doctor. And quite a competent one, if I say so as shouldn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll find it very dull -- snipping out tonsils and flushing out kidneys -- Watson is glancing around the room, searching for something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're looking for your medical bag, you hid it under the Moorish table. (as Watson crosses to it) Which shows a little more imagination than last time -- when it was under your bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Watson picks up the Moorish table, disclosing the medical bag, standing on end. He sets the bag down on the fender, opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will, of course, continue to pay my half of the rent until you find someone to share these rooms with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where am I going to find anyone who will put up with my rather eccentric habits?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking hypodermic needle out of bag) Here's a fresh needle -- and here's my farewell present to you. He takes out three bottles of narcotics, puts them on the mantel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want to destroy yourself, go right ahead. But I won't sit by and watch you doing it. He snaps his bag shut, carries it toward his bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watson... Watson disappears into the bedroom, slamming the door. Holmes looks after him, then looks at the bottles of dope on the mantelpiece. He starts pacing. After a moment he stops at the chemistry table, studies the assorted glassware on the shelves above. INT. WATSON'S BEDROOM - DAY There are two open valises on the bed. Watson is moving around the room, collecting various odds and ends, while Mrs. Hudson packs his clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so sad. You and Mr. Holmes -- after all these years -- (she sobs)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Mrs. Hudson -- none of that. Mrs. Hudson takes a clean handkerchief from the open valise, blows her nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll wash this and send it on to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be at Brown's Hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still sniffling) I know how it feels -- I once went through a divorce myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (removing diploma from wall) Actually, I'm rather looking forward to it. Leading a normal life again. Regular office hours -- nine to three -- and if occasionally there's an emergency call in the middle of the night, I know it's going be appendicitis and not an ax murder. Let Holmes go mucking about in the fog and the sleet, looking for a bloodstained collar-button out on the moors, with some demented hound snapping at his behind -- From the living room comes the sound of a revolver shot. Mrs. Hudson screams and Watson looks off in alarm. Then he races out of the room, diploma in hand, followed by Mrs. Hudson. INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY As they burst into the room, they see Holmes sitting on the stool beside the chemistry table, a revolver in his hand. He has shattered one of the narcotics bottles on the mantelpiece, and is aiming at a second one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Holmes... Holmes fires, smashing the second bottle. As Mrs. Hudson takes a step forward, he waves her away with the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Mrs. Hudson.    You're in my line of fire. Watson jerks Mrs.   Hudson back as Holmes lets go with another shot. The    bullet disposes of the third bottle, splattering glass   and liquid all over the place. Holmes rises calmly from   the stool, crosses to the desk, puts the revolver away   in a drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (outraged) How many times have I told you I will not tolerate pistol practice on my premises? I should have evicted you when you shot them holes in my wall. She points up to a spot near the ceiling. Neatly traced in bullet holes are the initials V.R., with a small crown above them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merely celebrating Her Majesty's Golden Jubilee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that mess you made -- Watson is looking at Holmes with a little smile on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right, Mrs. Hudson. I'll clean it up -- (hands her the diploma)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. LIVING ROOM - EVENING START on Holmes' foot, operating a bellows. CAMERA PANS UP to the top of the chemistry table, on which an elaborate apparatus of brass, glass and rubber tubing has been set up. Inserted into the ends of the rubber tubes are half a dozen cigarettes, four cigars of different shapes and colors, and four pipes, all lit. Activated by the bellows, they are puffing away like mad, wheezing loudly and filling the screen with smoke. Seated at the table is Holmes, in shirt-sleeves. Occasionally he knocks off an ash onto a glass slide, studies it under a microscope. Watson, in a dressing gown, is sitting in the chair with the writing arm, documenting the latest Holmes adventure for Strand Magazine. The open mail has now been affixed to the center of the wooden mantelpiece, with a dagger. Mrs. Hudson is clearing the dinner dishes from the table, and loading them onto the shelf of the dumbwaiter. The accumulation of smoke in the room makes her cough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: while you unpack my things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unpack?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard him. A bewildered Mrs. Hudson goes back into the bedroom. Watson crosses to the fireplace, picks up the whiskbroom and the coal shovel, starts cleaning up the broken glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Holmes. I know how difficult it must've been for you -- 17.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really. It was simple choice between a bad habit and a good companion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've made me very happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've often been accused of being cold and unemotional. I admit to it. And yet, in my cold, unemotional way, I'm very fond of you, Watson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that. But one likes to hear these things occasionally. He notices the violin, which has been splattered with the liquid from the shattered bottle, picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this. Covered with that nasty stuff. I'd better dry it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll do it. He takes the instrument, and dabbing it with a handkerchief, carries it toward the violin case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment, I was worried that you were going to let me walk out -- that you weren't even going to try to stop me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Watson -- you know there's nothing I wouldn't do to keep you here. With a side-glance at the busy Watson, he opens the violin case. Neatly stashed away around the edges are the three original bottles of narcotics. The ones he shot up, of course, were substitutes from the chemistry set. He places the violin carefully among the bottles, closes the case, snaps the locks. As he moves off, we STAY on the violin case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was not the first not the last time he tricked me like that. Normally, I was inclined to forgive him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But on one occasion, he did something that was so utterly unforgivable, that I would gladly have murdered him -- had it not been for my saintly disposition. Watson sets down his coffee cup, picks up the letter and the tickets, rises from his chair. He starts to pace -- addressing Holmes, who is off-scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you being so stubborn, Holmes? Why won't you go? It's the final performance of the Imperial Russian Ballet -- the house has been sold out for months -- He moves towards the door of -- HOLMES' BEDROOM - DAY Holmes is sitting in a hip-bath with a high back, soaping himself. Watson appears in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: seats are going for a guinea apiece -- HOLMES That's precisely it. Why should someone send up two free tickets? Anonymously, at that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoever sent them must be in great distress. The note says -- 19. (reading it) 'Please! You are the only man in the world who can help me.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suspect it's some sort of plot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean somebody wants to lure us into a trap...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody wants to kill me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kill you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. It's a plot to bore me to death. I detest ballet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But this isn't just any ballet.     It's Swan Lake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. THEATRE - NIGHT START ON THE CONDUCTOR, in the orchestra pit,   as he gives the downbeat for the second acto music of SWAN   LAKE. CAMERA PULLS BACK TO INCLUDE THE STAGE, with a   mechanical sway crossing the mist-shrouded lake. CAMERA    CONTINUES TO PULL BACK, REVEALING Holmes and Watson, in   evening clothes, occupying a box in the upper tier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (confidentially) You know, of course, Holmes -- that swan isn't really a swan -- it's an enchanted princess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (bored) H'mmmm. On the stage now, the hunters appear, carrying lighted torches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BOX Watson trains his opera glasses on the stage, Holmes stifles a yawn. STAGE PETROVA, as the Queen of the Swans, makes her entrance to loud applause. She is in her forties, but splendidly preserved, undoubtedly the greatest ballerina around. BOX Watson nudges Holmes, who has dozed off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fabulous woman, don't you think so, Holmes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coming to) Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The great Petrova. He hands the glasses to Holmes, who focuses them indifferently on the stage. STAGE Petrova is making an exit, backwards, on points. BOX Holmes lowers the glasses, returns them to Watson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very strong arches, I must admit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They say twelve men have died for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six committed suicide, four were killed in duels, and one fell out of the gallery in the Vienna Opera House.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's only eleven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man who fell from the gallery landed on top of another man in the orchestra.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That makes an even dozen -- in a messy sort of way. Watson resumes watching the stage through the glasses. STAGE Petrova and the dancer playing the Prince go into the famous pas-de-deux. BOX Watson enjoying himself immensely, Holmes sitting there dourly. The red plush curtain at the rear of the box parts, and a man in evening clothes and a top hat enters. He is in his middle fifties, extremely soigne, and somewhat sinister. His name is ROGOZHIN, and he is Russian. Holmes and Watson look around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Holmes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am Nicolai Rogozhin, director-general of the Imperial Russian Ballet. So glad you accept invitation. Holmes and Watson start to get up, but he motions them back into their chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Dr. Watson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pleased to meet you. (seating himself behind them) You are enjoying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Immensely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (abruptly) Tell me, Mr. Holmes, how is your health?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My health?   Better consult my doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Rogozhin) Oh, he's in excellent shape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Holmes) Any insanity in your family?   Diabetes? Asthma?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you mind telling me what this is all about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly.   Madame Petrova, she has problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you be more specific?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A liason with a crowned head? Compromising letters? Blackmail? He glances toward the stage. STAGE The pas-de-deux finished, to a rousing ovation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BOX Rogozhin rises, turns to Holmes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After performance, there will be little celebration backstage -- and Madame requests your presence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd be delighted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Watson) You are invited, also. With a parting look he exits, pulling the plush curtains closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : STAGE The performance is over, the curtain is up, the party is on. Tables have been set up, with caviar, vodka and champagne. The members of the orchestra are now playing balalaikas, and crew and cast (the ballerinas still in costume, the male dancers in tights) seem in high spirits. Holmes and Watson, in silk hats with canes, appear from the wings, stop, survey the scene. Watson's eyes are shining with anticipation. In contrast, Holmes' face is sober and quizzical. Rogozhin spots the two, detaches himself from a group, hurries over to join them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There you are, Mr. Holmes. Madame is expecting you in her dressing room. Dr. Watson, you will amuse yourself meanwhile
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY Watson, in his dressing gown, is sitting at the table, finishing his coffee. In front of him is a letter, on blue note-paper, and a pair of theatre tickets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: we have vodka, caviar, girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No girls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No caviar. Makes me break out in hives. Rogozhin turns to a group of ballerinas, claps his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dievushki. Siude, siuda, dievushki. Posnakomtes s docktorum Watsonom. Half a dozen ballerinas descend on on Dr. Watson. They are giggling and chattering in Russian. Rogozhin leads Holmes off, while Watson takes in the bevy of beauties around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any of you girls understand English?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nyet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not one single word?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nyet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In that case, I don't mind telling you that you all have lovely po-pos. He pats a couple of the po-pos with his cane. BACKSTAGE Rogozhin is leading Holmes toward Madame Petrova's dressing room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Holmes, I must prepare you -- this is no ordinary case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is only the extraordinary that interests me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Because you will find this extra- extraordinary. They have now reached the door of Madame's dressing room. Rogozhin knocks. The door is opened by an elderly Russian maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame Petrova prinimaet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pozhaluista voidite. Rogozhin leads Holmes inside.    The maid steps out, shuts the door. INT. DRESSING ROOM - NIGHT It is small, elegant and sensuous. There is vodka in an ice-bucket, next to a Recamier chaise, a paravent, masses of flowers, and finally Madame Petrova, still in costume, sitting at a dressing table with multiple mirrors, undoing her hair. Candles, in two elaborate candleabra, give Madame's face a special glow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ja priviol vam Mistera Sherlock Holmesa, doragaia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Holmes) Otchen rada. She extends her hand, and Holmes takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame. He kisses her hand. Petrova appraises him from head to toe, and back again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Holmes) Vi menshe rostom chem ja ozhidala.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame says you are shorter than she thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't mean to be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No eto nie vazhno. Menia interessujut glavnim obra som vashi mosghi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Short, tall, who cares?   It is the brains that count.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Rogozhin) Thank you. (catching himself, to Petrova) Thank you. Petrova rises, crosses to the paravent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ja prochia vsie vashi prikliuchenia. Zamiechatelno! Os sobenno sobaka Baskervillei.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame is great admirer of yours. She has read every story -- her favorite is Big Dog from Baskerville.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid it loses something in translation. Petrova is now behind the paravent, undressing, only her head visible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nikolai, pokazhite iemu skripku. Rogozhin picks up a violin case, opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Holmes, you know about fiddles. (takes violin out, hands it to him) What is your opinion of this? Holmes holds the violin up, peers through one of the sound holes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reading) 'Antonius Stradivarius Cremonesis, Anno
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .' Well, the label is authentic. (examines violin, plucks strings) Judging from the shape, the color of the varnish, and the tone, I would say it is a genuine Stradivarius of the best period.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's magnificent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (from behind paravent) Skazhite jemu chto eto podarok ot menia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here -- take it. Madame says it is yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For services you will render.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My fees as a detective are not exactly trifling -- but a Stradivarius -- you're not serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not.   But Madame is. Petrova emerges from behind the paravent, in a brocade dressing gown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nalejte vodki i obiasnite jemu v chom dielo. She drapes herself on the chaise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right.   I will pour vodka and explain. (starts pouring vodka; it is pink) Mr. Holmes, what you have seen tonight is last and positively final performance of Madame Petrova. She is retiring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a shame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has been dancing since she was three years old. And after all, she is now thirty-eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gallantly) I must say she doesn't look thirty-eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is because she is   forty-nine. (he hands her a   glass of vodka, with an   exaggerated smile) So Madame has decided   to leave ballet and spend life bringing up   her child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How admirable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hands him vodka) Problem now is to find father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh?   Is he missing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Correct.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's why you called me in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Also correct. We must have father, because without father, how can there be child?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. The whole thing is still in the planning stage -- ROGOZHIN Correct again. Madame would like child to be brilliant and beautiful. Since she is beautiful -- she now needs man who is brilliant. Holmes' eyes wander slowly toward Petrova.    She raises her glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Za zdorovie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (raising his glass) Za zdorovie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Za zdrovie. Petrova and Rogozhin down their vodka bottoms up.    Holmes takes one swallow, then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's in it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does it taste like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red pepper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what's in it. While Rogozhin refills Petrova's glass and his own, Holmes takes another tentative sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Holmes) Kogda mi smozhem dvinutsa v putj?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame wants to know how soon you can be ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To leave for Venice. All arrangements have been made. You will spend one week there with Madame...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, this is all very flattering. But surely there are other me -- better men -- ROGOZHIN To tell you truth, you were not first choice. We considered Russian writer, Tolstoi -- HOLMES That's more like it.   The man's a genius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too old... Then we considered the philosopher, Nietzsche -- HOLMES Absolutely first-rate mind...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too German... And we considered Tschaikowski -- HOLMES Oh, you couldn't go wrong with Tschaikowski -- ROGOZHIN We could -- and we did.   It was catastrophe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know? Because Tschaikowski -- how shall put it? Women not his glass of tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pity, that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Rogozhin) Skazhite jemu chto je otchen dovolna etim resheniem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame is very happy with final choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame mustn't be too hasty.   She must remember I'm an Englishman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what they say about us. If there's one thing more deplorable than our cooking, it's our love-making. We are not exactly the most romantic of people -- ROGOZHIN Perfect. We don't want sentimental idiots -- falling in love, committing suicide. One week in Venice -- she goes back to St. Petersburg with baby -- you go back to London with fiddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An equitable arrangement. (puts down violin) About my medical history -- when you asked me -- I neglected to mention a small detail. There is hemophilia in my family. We're all bleeders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Petrova) On govorit, chto v jevo semie stradajut ghemofilijei.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pust nie bezpokoitsa.    Ja ostrighu sebe noghti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame says not to worry.    She will not scratch you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's reassuring to know.    But -- PETROVA (to Rogozhin) Pochemu on kolebletsa? On nie nahodit menia dostatochno privlekatelnoi?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame says you talk too much.    You find her attractive or no? Before Holmes can answer, the door opens and Watson sticks his head in. He is flushed and slightly inebriated, and there is a flower tucked behind his ear. From off comes the SOUND of wild balalaika music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. (to Rogozhin) What does prokanzik mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It means 'You little devil.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It does?   I am? Thank you. He hurries off, shutting the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Holmes) I repeat question. You find Madame attractive or no? Holmes is still looking at the door where Watson exited, an idea forming in his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning to Rogozhin) Oh, I find her most attractive -- for a woman, that is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then no problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe a slight one.       You see, I am not a free man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not free?   You are a bachelor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bachelor -- living with another bachelor -- for the last five years. Five very happy years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it you are trying to tell me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hoped I could avoid the subject. But some of us -- through a cruel caprice of Mother Nature -- ROGOZHIN Get to point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The point is that Tschaikowski is not an isolated case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, you and Dr. Watson -- ? (Holmes nods) He is your glass of tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want to be picturesque about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slightly agitated) Chto on govorit? Pri chom tut Chaikovsky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On pederast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (on her feet now; flaring) Jescho odin? Eto stanovitsa odnoobrasno! Kakoi vi idiot!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (picking up his silk hat and cane) Believe me, Madame, the loss is all mine. But I would prefer to disappoint you know than disappoint you in a gondola in Venice. He takes her limp hand, kisses it.   Then he crosses to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (imitating Rogozhin's accent) It would have been catastrophe. He exits.   Rogozhin starts to pour himself another glass of vodka.   Petrova slaps the glass out of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (screaming) Potchemu vi nie vijasnili eto eto ranshe, prezhde chem posoritj menia! STAGE The party has built into a real wingding by now. It's wild -- drinking, laughing, singing. Everybody is turned on -- especially Watson. He is dancing with a dozen of the ballerinas to madly accelerating balalaika music. Flower behind ear, hair mussed, tie undone, short of breath -- he is in paradise. Holmes makes his way through the revelers, approaches Watson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watson! (Watson pays no attention) Watson, are you coming?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (without missing a step) What is it, old boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Home? Not a chance. Not the slightest -- not the remotest chance. Toodle-ooo. He waves goodbye, and goes on swirling dizzily with the girls. Holmes puts on his silk hat and leaves. A shaken Rogozhin comes up to the buffet, pours himself a stiff drink of vodka. As he drinks his eyes follow the dancing Watson balefully. Watson spins off several of the girls, grabs another group. His ex-partners wind up close to Rogozhin. He whispers something to them. Their eyes widen, and they stare at Watson with disbelief. Watson again switches partners, and the first girls now whisper intensely to those who just left the floor. The same reaction. Watson, oblivious to all this, is whirling around with another set of girls. By now some of the girls who are in on the secret are whispering to the male dancers in tights. Their reaction is slightly different. They are seeing Watson in a new light. And before Watson knows what's happening, he has been abandoned by all the girls, and is joined first by one pair then another pair of male dancers, till he is dancing only with gay guys in tights. It gradually dawns on Watson that there is something wrong with this state of affairs. After some difficulty, he breaks away from them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on!    Just a moment! Spotting Rogozhin, he crosses to him.   The girls shrink away at his approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (bewildered) What's going on? What happened to the girls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?   Do you not prefer it this way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to pretend. Mr. Holmes told us everything -- about you and him -- WATSON About me and him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come now, no need to be bashful. We are not bourgeois. Maybe with doctors and detectives is unusual -- but in ballet, is very usual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Caprice of Mother Nature. Look at Pavel and Mischa and Boris and Dmitri -- Watson looks around at the boys in tights, who are standing in a half-circle, grinning at him insolently. It is beginning to dawn on him. He pales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Ilya and Sergei -- (breaks off, rocks his hand back and forth) Sergei -- half and half. He pours himself another vodka. Watson grabs the glass away from him, downs it with a gulp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. BAKER STREET - NIGHT An enraged Watson, cane and opera glasses in hand, and the flower still behind his ear, is jogging down the center of the deserted street. INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Holmes rises casually, twists the wing chair so that its back is to the door, crosses to the lamp on the desk, turns the wick down. From off comes the sound of Watson's key rattling in the front door lock. STAIRCASE - 221B BAKER STREET - NIGHT The front door opens and Watson storms into the vestibule.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes! He races up the stairs and across the landing, flings open the door of the flat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes! INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Watson, grim and breathless, stands in the open doorway. Over the back of the wing chair, he sees smoke curling up from Holmes' pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There you are, you wretch! You rotter! You blackguard! Of all the vile, unspeakable fabrications. What do you have to say for yourself? No answer from Holmes. We now see -- but Watson does not -- that the chair is occupied by a section of Holmes' smoking machine, with the pipe attached.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't just sit there -- speak up, man!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Still no answer -- just a little pipe smoke drifting up from the wing chair. Incensed, Watson raises the opera glasses, tosses them toward the chair. There is a loud thud, the pipe falls to the floor, then there is silence. Watson suddenly becomes concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes...?   Are you all right, Holmes? He approaches the chair apprehensively, shoves  it aside -- and there on the floor is the smoking machine,  still wheezing slightly. Watson picks it up, and his   eyes travel to Holmes, standing in a shadowy corner,  working the bellows with his foot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the sound of your footsteps, I gathered that you were not in a particularly amiable mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with renewed fury) How could you do a dastardly thing like that to me? What the deuce were you thinking of? He dashes the smoking machine to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watson, you  have my most abject apologies.   But have you ever been cornered by  a madwoman?  It seemed like the only way  to get out of it without hurting her  feelings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about my feelings? And my reputation? Do you realize the gravity of what you have done? The possible repercussions?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So there'll be a little gossip about you in St. Petersburg...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These things spread like wildfire. I can just hear those malicious whispers behind my back. I'll never be able to show my face in polite society...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . And if it ever got back to my old regiment -- you don't know the Fifth Northumberland Fusiliers -- they'll strike me off the rolls -- they'll cut off my pension...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watson, you're running amok.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dishonored, disgraced, ostracized.   What am I to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, for one thing, I'd get rid of that flower. He points to the flower behind Watson's ear. Watson grabs the flower, hurls it into the fireplace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may think this is funny, but we're both in the same boat. We must take desperate measures. We must stop this talk... (a beat, then an idea) Maybe if we got married...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then they'd really talk...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (starts pacing) Obviously, we cannot continue to live under the same roof. We must move apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, we can still see each other clandestinely -- on remote benches in Hyde Park, and in the waiting rooms of suburban railway stations -- WATSON (a change in attitude; defiant) The whole thing is ridiculous.   We have nothing to hide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I've been trying to tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let somebody start a rumor -- just one ugly word -- and we'll sue them for slander.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody would dare. After all, you have an enviable record with the fair sex.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn right. I can get women from three continents to testify for me. And you can get women to vouch for you, too -- can't you, Holmes? No answer from Holmes.   Watson is becoming a little concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you, Holmes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, Watson. He starts toward his bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes, let me ask you a question -- (Holmes stops) I hope I'm not being presumptuous -- but there have been women in your life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The answer is yes. (a relieved sigh from Watson) You're being presumptuous. (Watson's face falls) Good night. He walks into his bedroom, shutting the door.    Watson takes a tentative step after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. LIVING ROOM - 221B BAKER STREET - NIGHT There is a cheery fire burning in the grate. Holmes is stretched out full-length on the couch, playing a set of Corelli variations on his violin. Watson is in his usual chair, reading the Evening Standard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, indeed, was his attitude toward women? Was there some secret he was holding back -- or was he just a thinking machine, incapable of any emotion? EXT. BAKER STREET - NIGHT Wisps of fog swirl along the street, making yellow haloes around street lamps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was not to get the answer until we became involved in what I consider to be the most outrageous case in all our years together. Out of the mist comes a hansom cab, with the dim figure of a woman visible in the passenger seat. The cab stops in front of 221B, and the driver starts to get down. From upstairs comes the faint sound of violin music. INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Watson steps up to the window, pulls the curtain aside, looks down toward the street. EXT. 221B BAKER STREET - NIGHT The cabbie crosses the pavement, consults an address in his hand, glances up at the number of the house, then rings the bell. INT. LIVING ROOM - 221B BAKER STREET - NIGHT Watson turns away from the window, as the BELL downstairs rings again. Holmes stops playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you expecting someone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at this hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe Mrs. Hudson is entertaining.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never found her so. Watson crosses to the door, opens it, steps out.   Holmes resumes playing Corelli. VESTIBULE AND STAIRCASE - 221B BAKER STREET - NIGHT Mrs. Hudson, in a robe and night-cap, is talking to the cabbie in the open street door when Watson appears on the landing above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, Mrs. Hudson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking up) There's a cabbie here -- he says you owe him two-and-six.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Watson) For the fare, guv'nor. The young lady doesn't have any money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What young lady?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one. He reaches out the door, pulls in the young lady in question. She is in her early thirties, with strikingly handsome features, but at the moment she is somewhat worse for wear. She is wrapped in a blanket, her hair is wet, and there is a bruise on her temple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She is wearing and wedding ring and her name, we will subsequently learn, is GABRIELLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well.  What have we here? (he starts down the stairs) Who are you, miss? What happened to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slight accent) I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all she keeps saying -- I don't know, I don't know. The violin music stops o.s.   Watson has now reached the foot of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did she come from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the river. I was driving down the Embankment, just below Westminster Bridge, and there she was in the water -- drowning. Holmes appears on the landing above, violin and bow in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't easy, guv'nor -- what with the cold water -- and her fighting me -- HOLMES (from the upper landing) Why did you bring her here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I found this in her hand -- (gives a square of soggy cardboard to Watson)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. LIVING ROOM - 221B BAKER STREET - NIGHT In contrast to the frenetic ambiance of the back-stage party, the room seems doubly placid. Holmes, his dinner coat replaced by a smoking jacket, is sitting in the wing chair, having a quiet pipe after the evening's peculiar adventure. Only the desk lamp is lit. From the street, there is the sound of hurried, angry footsteps approaching the house. Holmes turns his head languidly -- he knows who is coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Baker Street -- that's right, isn't it? Watson examines the cardboard, nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Gabrielle) Young lady -- what did you want at this address?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking up, trying to focus) I do not remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Holmes) Rather perplexing, wouldn't you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, gentlemen, you want her? -- it's two-and-six -- or shall I throw her back in the river?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Holmes.   You can't let him -- HOLMES Watson, you'd better accept delivery. Watson fishes some coins out of his pocket, hands them to the cabbie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep the change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, guv'nor. He snatches the blanket off Gabrielle, revealing that her dress is clinging to her damply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No extra charge for the use of the horse- blanket. He exits into the street, shutting the door.    Gabrielle hugs herself for warmth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're shivering, my dear. (he puts his arm around her)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Come along. Let me get you out of those wet clothes. He starts to lead her up the stairs. EXT. BAKER STREET - NIGHT The cabbie has tossed the blanket into the hansom, and is mounting the driver's seat. Across the street, a man steps out of the fog into a pool of light cast by one of the street lamps. He is a craggy-faced Prussian of about fifty, and his name is VON TIRPITZ. He looks up toward the Holmes flat. As the hansom makes a U-turn and comes abreast of him, he hops into the cab. The hansom disappears into the fog. INT. LIVING ROOM - 221B BAKER STREET - NIGHT Watson is leading Gabrielle to a chair by the fireplace. Holmes is putting his violin down on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit here, my dear. He settles her in the chair. Holmes comes over, plucks the square of cardboard from Watson's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's suffering from shock and exposure. He starts to massage her wrists to restore her circulation. Holmes is examining the soggy cardboard. On one side is their address, written in pencil. He turns it over, disclosing some smudges of green ink on the other side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was some printing on the back of this -- but it seems to have come off in the water. Watson is now studying the bruise on Gabrielle's temple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this -- she's had a nasty blow on the head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could she have hit her head when she fell or jumped into the river?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. The blood has already coagulated. So it would appear that she was the victim of a deliberate attack... Get my bag, will you? As Holmes fetches the medical bag, Gabrielle looks from one to the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Dr. Watson -- and this is Mr. Sherlock Holmes. Do the names mean anything to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you think of your own name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a beat, then shakes her head) No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's obviously had a concussion -- which often leads to temporary amnesia. He has now taken some cotton and a bottle of antiseptic out of the medical bag, and is swabbing her wound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So all we know is that she was coshed on the head, dumped into the Thames, and subsequently dumped into our laps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We know a lot more than that. From her accent, we know she is foreign -- from her ring, we know she is married -- and there is one other clue we have... Something I deduced while I was helping her up the stairs. No corset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good work. He glances down at Gabrielle's shoe, which has slipped off her foot. Inside, slightly worn away, are the words: LA FEMME ELEGANTE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Gabrielle) Are you French? (in Berlitz French) Vous etes Francaise?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (concentrating -- then) Non, je ne suis pas Francaise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can she say she's not French, in French?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vous etes Suisse?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Non.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alors, vous etes Belge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (haltingly) Je suis pas sure. Holmes reaches behind her, turns back the collar of her dress. Sewn inside is a label reading: BAZAAR MODERN, Bruxelles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vous etes Belge -- de Bruxelles!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bruxelles?    Oui... Je pense que oui. Mrs. Hudson has come in with a loaded tea-tray, starts to put it down on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, dash. Will someone remove the violin, please? Watson takes the violin off the table, and she sets down the tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We just found out that she's Belgian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poor thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Brussels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking Gabrielle's hand) If you don't mind. He slips the wedding ring off her finger, picks up a magnifying glass, examines it. It is made of copper, and engraved on the inside is the inscription: Gabrielle - Emile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your name is Gabrielle, is that right? Gabrielle?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And your husband's name is Emile?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (vaguely) Emile...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he? What are you doing in London?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you arrive from Brussels?     Where are you staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened at the river?   Think! Pensez! Concentrez vous! Gabrielle bursts into sobs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stepping forward) That's enough, Holmes. I will not permit you to question her in this condition. (helps the sobbing Gabrielle out of the chair) Mrs. Hudson, put her to bed. My bed. (Mrs. Hudson gives him a look) I'll sleep on the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, my dear. She puts her arm around Gabrielle, who is still crying, leads her into Watson's bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd better mix her a sleeping potion. He gets a packet of white powder out of his medical bag, and during the following, stirs a spoonful into her tea- cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watson, I think we should arrange to have her removed to a hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Under no circumstances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She should have medical attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can get that from me. But more importantly, she must be protected -- there has already been one attempt on her life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This temporary amnesia -- how temporary is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It depends on the extent of the injury. It's like veils shrouding her memory. It could clear up in a few days -- or a few weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watson, this is a very small flat -- we don't want to clutter it up with women...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes, we've never had a case like this. A woman comes to us with a problem -- we don't know who the woman is -- and we don't know what the problem is. Don't you find that challenging?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite. But we can't afford to wait for those veils to lift -- we must break through them as quickly as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You   really feel it's that urgent?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do. The sooner we solve the case, the sooner we can get rid of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. He picks up the cup of tea with the sedative in it, carries it toward the door of his bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. BAKER STREET - DAWN The street lamps are still lit. A policeman, on patrol duty, is strolling along the sidewalk, swinging his truncheon. Suddenly he sees something up ahead. Alarmed, he ducks into the doorway of a building, flattens himself against the door. From the opposite direction comes a horse-drawn water- sprinkling wagon. The spray covers the sidewalks as well as the street. The policeman waits till the wagon is past, then steps out of the doorway relieved, resumes his patrol. INT. LIVING ROOM - 221B BAKER STREET - DAWN Watson is asleep on the couch, covered with a blanket. He doesn't look as if he were in a very comfortable position. INT. HOLMES' BEDROOM - DAWN Holmes, in a dressing gown, is standing by the window, studying the square of cardboard with the green smudges on it. His bed has not been slept in. INT. WATSON'S BEDROOM - DAWN Gabrielle is asleep in Watson's bed. The door opens slowly, and Holmes looks in. He studies the sleeping Gabrielle for a moment, then quietly pulls the door shut. As the latch clicks into place, Gabrielle awakes and sits up in bed, her back to CAMERA. She is nude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emile? She starts to get out of bed. INT. HOLMES' BEDROOM - DAWN Holmes is back in his room, once more examining the cardboard by the light of the window. The door of Watson's bedroom opens, and Gabrielle comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emile? Holmes looks up as Gabrielle appears in the open doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emile?   Is that you, Emile?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stepping into shadow) Yes, Gabrielle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hurrying toward him) Ah, Emile. I thought I'd never find you. (embracing him) Hold me. Hold me tight. (Holmes puts his arms around her) It's been such a long time. So many nights. You know what I did before I left Brussels?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you won't be angry with me. I bought myself an expensive negligee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (moving toward bed) A pink negligee with maribou feathers. Don't you think that's a foolish thing for a married woman? (she gets into bed, beckons to him) Come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is the negligee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In my luggage... Come here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (moving toward her) And where is your luggage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (impatiently) I don't know. Come, my love.   Come. Please. As she extends her right hand to him, in a beckoning gesture, Holmes notices something on the palm. He takes her hand in his. There, in the same green ink as the smudges on the cardboard, are what appear the be the letters "I", "O", and Greek "E". Crossing to the wash- stand, he picks up his magnifying shaving mirror, returns to the bed, holds it up against the palm of Gabrielle's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, Emile? What are you doing? Clearly reflected in the mirror is the reverse image of the lettering on Gabrielle's palm -- the number "301".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Watson! (she claps her hands and he wakes up) Your porridge is getting lumpy. Hadn't you better get up? Watson tries to rise, falls back with a moan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would like to very much. But -- (he turns over on his stomach) Mrs. Hudson, would you mind planting your knee in the small of my back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I would.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please!   I'm in excruciating pain. Mrs. Hudson tentatively rests her knee on Watson's back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bit higher -- just below my seventh vertebra -- (Mrs. Hudson follows instructions) That's good. Put your arms under mine -- fold them behind my neck -- Mrs. Hudson presses down harder, and there is a distinct snap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bless you. (he rises, rubbing his neck) That damn couch. (crossing to table) You'd better see if our patient is awake. He seats himself at the table. Mrs. Hudson crosses to the door of Watson's bedroom, opens it, starts inside, then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Watson.   She's gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gone? He jumps up from the table, joins Mrs. Hudson, looks past her. The bed is empty. Gabrielle's clothes are in evidence, but there is no sign of her. Watson strides towards Holmes' bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmes!   Holmes! She's gone! He throws the door open, is about to step inside when he sees something that makes him freeze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. HOLMES' BEDROOM - DAY Gabrielle is asleep in Holmes' bed, covered by just a sheet, and obviously naked underneath. Holmes is not in the room. Mrs. Hudson comes up behind Watson, in the open doorway, peers over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (scandalized) Well, I never! There is the sound of the hall door opening, and they both turn. INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY Holmes breezes in, carrying a large suitcase, with leather straps around it. Tucked under the straps is a white parasol. And attached to the handle of the suitcase is a cardboard tag with the number 301 on it, in green.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (inhaling deeply) Mmmmm. I smell porridge.   Lumpy as usual, I suppose. He sets the suitcase down on the couch, as Watson and Mrs. Hudson approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, there you are, Holmes. We were just wondering -- how -- (points from his bedroom to Holmes')
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sternly) We certainly were.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Hudson, why don't you go down to the kitchen -- get a towel -- and wipe that look of disapproval off your face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liberties -- in my house! She exits huffily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't really blame her -- I mean, the way it looks -- if I didn't know you better, I might suspect you'd taken advantage of the young lady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a matter of fact, I did take advantage of her... Would you hand me the butter- knife, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. He picks up the butter-knife from the table, suddenly turns back with a delayed reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking butter-knife from him) Thank you. He starts to pry open the locks of the suitcase with the butter-knife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (spluttering) Holmes, this is reprehensible! Where are your professional ethics? Have you no sense of decency, no shame -- HOLMES None whatsoever. If you must know, I found her body quite rewarding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cad!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Especially the palm of her right hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd rather not hear about it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well. Then I won't bother to tell you how I traced her suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's her suitcase?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember that piece of soggy cardboard with our address on it? It was a luggage ticket -- the number rubbed off on her hand. And since she must have arrived from Brussels by the boat train, I concluded that she had checked her belongings at Victoria Station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By Jove! If you're right, we should find a clue to her identity. Holmes has now forced open the locks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or at least a pink negligee with maribou feathers. He opens the suitcase, lifts out the top piece of clothing, holds it up -- a pink negligee with maribou feathers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Voila!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's see - what else is in here? They start sorting through the clothes in the suitcase. Holmes removes a tied bundle of letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we're getting somewhere. As he examines the envelope, Watson takes out a framed photo of a rather attractive man of fifty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who do you suppose this is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gabrielle appears from Holmes' bedroom wearing Holmes' dressing gown. She is unsteady on her feet and somewhat dazed. Holmes looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in, Madame Valladon. (Gabrielle stops) You are Gabrielle Valladon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (holding up photo) And this is your husband, Emile Valladon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Her eyes fall on the open suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry to have ransacked your valise.     But since you came to us for help -- GABRIELLE Where am I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baker Street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes... (a beat, as she orients herself) Which of you is Mr. Holmes and which is Dr. Watson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Watson is the handsome one. Watson, pleased, twirls the end of his mustache. Gabrielle sways slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the way he affects most women. He helps her into a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Gabrielle) Coffee. You want strong coffee. He hurries over to the breakfast table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all so confusing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's try to sort it out. You came to London looking for your husband...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He's a mining engineer. We were married five years ago, in the Congo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where your husband was working in a copper mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your wedding ring -- it's made of copper. He picks it up from the chemistry table, hands it to her. Gabrielle starts to put it on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last year he invented a new kind of air pump, and was hired by an English company, Jonah Limited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (handing her cup of of coffee) Here you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jonah Limited. Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've been writing to each other regularly. Then suddenly,  three weeks ago, his letters stopped.  I kept writing ... but no answer. Finally  I decided to go to that address -- 60. She indicates the bundle of letters. Holmes glances at the return address on the back of the envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ashdown Street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It's just an empty store -- nobody there. Then I tried to find Jonah Limited. No such company exists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How decidedly odd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame Valladon, can you think of any reason why your husband should have lied to you about theses things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emile?   Never. He loves me -- and I love him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I gathered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went to the police -- they said they would send out a missing persons report -- but they didn't sound too encouraging. Then I went to the Belgian embassy and explained the situation to them -- and they suggested that I consult you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could have done worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was on my way here -- and suddenly there were footsteps behind me -- and a hand over my mouth -- and the smell of choloroform -- and the next thing I knew I was in the water -- and then a man was wrapping me in a blanket -- HOLMES Madame Valladon, somebody tried to kill you last night. Do you have any idea who could have done it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand any of it. (rises, goes to Holmes) What does it all mean, Mr. Holmes? Where is my husband? You must help me find him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll do our best, I assure you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame Valladon, I want you to send one more letter to your husband. He crosses to the desk, picks up a sheet of paper and an envelope, then leads Gabrielle over to the chair with the writing arm, seats her in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To Emile Valladon -- Ashdown Street -- what was that number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (addressing envelope)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. LIVING ROOM - 221B BAKER STREET - DAY The table is set for breakfast, and Mrs. Hudson is opening the curtains, flooding the room with sunlight. Then she moves over to the couch, where Watson is sleeping in an awkward position.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . What do you want me to say in the letter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. He folds the blank sheet of paper, and as Gabrielle finishes addressing the envelope, he inserts the paper in it, starts to seal it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sending an empty sheet of paper to an empty shop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That empty shop is obviously    being used as an accomodation address,    or letter- drop. But what gets dropped     must be picked up. The question is     how? -- and by whom? -- and why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. ASHDOWN STREET - DAY This is a run-down district in the northwestern part of London. On the corner is No. 32 -- a dilapidated abandoned shop, with windows painted halfway up. As CAMERA APPROACHES the building, we hear sawing from inside. INT. EMPTY SHOP - DAY It is dusty, cobwebby, quite forbidding. In the rear wall is a closed sliding door, indented about a foot into the shop. Nearby stands a large, square object, covered with a tarpaulin. High up in the rear wall is a slanted skylight, fitted with an iron grill. From outside, Holmes, in deerstalker and Inverness, can be seen sawing through the iron bars. Watson and Gabrielle are beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hammer... Chisel. Watson hands him the indicated tools. Holmes chips away the cement from the top and bottom of the last bar, then using it as a hinge, swings the grill open. He lets himself through the skylight, drops to the floor. Watson now helps Gabrielle through the skylight, lowers her toward Holmes, who puts his arms around her waist, eases her to the floor. For a brief moment he keeps his arms around her. Watson has now squeezed through the skylight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here! He hands the tools to Holmes, jumps to the floor. Gabrielle is looking around the shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so strange to think I've been writing to a place like this all these months. Watson crosses to the square tarpaulin-covered object. He lifts up one corner of the tarp -- and is greeted by a loud twittering of birds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . What he has uncovered is a large cage -- and about a hundred canaries, suddenly disturbed, are flapping around unside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at all these canaries. Do you suppose this could have been a pet shop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe. (pointing off) Here comes our letter. Through the front window, the silhouette of a postman can be seen approaching. He drops a letter through the slot in the front door, moves on. The letter lands on a section of floor which is solidly covered with dust -- except for a series of double tracks, running to the door and curving back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we are faced with the most nerve- wracking part of the detective's job -- doing nothing. He reassembles the three tools, fitting each section into another, to form a cane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Holmes -- HOLMES Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how I'm going to pay you for all this. The purse with my money is somewhere at the bottom of the Thames.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It could be worse. You could be at the bottom of the Thames -- much to your discomfort -- and much to my chagrin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand how anybody picks up letters here. (pointing) No footprints -- just tracks. What does it mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would surmise somebody is using ice- skates -- if it weren't for a conspicuous absence of ice. They become aware of a squeaking noise outside the rear of the shop, growing louder as it gets nearer. The noise stops, there is the sound of a lock turning, then the rattle of a chain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a frantic whisper) What do we do now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (unfazed) This way. He leads Gabrielle and Watson toward the rear wall, right next to the door. They flatten themselves with their backs to the wall, just as the door slides open -- concealing them from view. Revealed is the mews behind the shop. In the door is an old BIDDY with straggly hair, sitting in a wheelchair. In her lap are a bulky paper bag and a tin pitcher filled with water. As she wheels herself inside, the unoiled wheelchair squeaks loudly. She stops in front of the cage, pulls on a rope which runs through a pulley in the ceiling -- and the tarpaulin rises into the air, exposing the canaries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (addressing birds) Good morning, my pretties. Here's Mum with your breakfast. Did you think I'd forgotten you? She pours grain from the paper bag into a feeder hanging inside the cage, pours water from the pitcher into a trough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some  of you will be going on a little trip  soon -- I hate to lose you -- but even  an old woman has to live. Although you  might well ask, why? She cackles to herself, glances toward the front door.
direction.name: direction
